name: SiebelReview: Check No Match Property Set to TRUE for MVLs
description:
"For MVLs, configuring a Primary Join will result in the following behavior when Check No Match has been set to FALSE:
When the application encounters a master record where the primary foreign key is NULL or invalid, it performs a secondary query to determine if there are detail records in the multi-value group.  If it finds there are no detail records, it sets the primary field to the special value "No Match Row Id".  When the application encounters a master record again where the primary foreign key has the value "No Match Row Id", this indicates to the system that there are no detail records in the multi-value group and the secondary query should not be performed.
When the Check No Match property is set to TRUE and the application encounters a master record where the primary foreign key is NULL, "No Match Row Id", or is invalid, the object manager performs a secondary query to determine if there are detail records in the multi-value group.  In other words, the application does not accept the accuracy of the special value "No Match Row Id" when determining if a child record may exist, and performs the additional query anyway.
Setting the Check No Match property to TRUE can cause poor performance in an environment with a high number of parent records without primary child records, especially in list applets, as the application is forced to check the existence of child records by executing secondary queries."
output: This rule reports Multi-Value Links with No Match property set to FALSE
rationale: The Check No Match property on the MVL object has been set to TRUE for several new MVLs.  This property controls the behavior of the application when an MVL uses a primary join and the primary ID field has the value special value "No Match Row Id".
total: Number of added or modified Multi-Value Links
